body.p:
Louisville Ky Jan 20th 1860
His Excellency,
B Magoffin Govr of Kentucky,

The undersigned would represent that, at the January Term 1860 of the City Court of Louisville, a fine of fifty Dollars & cost was imposed upon him, upon an indictment Charging him, with Selling to a Slave, Whisky, Said slave belonging to one John McGaugh, the indictment charges that the Same was sold to the slave on the 8th of December 1859,

Now your petitoner Solemly avers that the true facts of the Case and these, He says that he Keeps a Tavern, near the Pork house of A. S. White & Co, at the head of Jefferson Street in the City of Louisville Ky, and that said slave was hired by his owner to work at sd pork house, and that on the day named in said in said indictment a white man came into the Tavern of the undersigned, with said slave, and represented that he was one of the managers of said pork house -- that the slave was in his Employ & directed me to let him have a Dram of whisky, I done so, never thinking but that the white man was authorized to Call for the Drink, I have lived in Louisville many years & this is the first charge Ever brought against me, no man is more opposed to Violating the law then I am, and the negro never should have had the whisky if I had not of believed the white man Controled him, In view of all the facts of the case I trust your Excellency will remit said fine,

I was the attorney of H Berlin in the above Case, and am Satisfied Berlin's Statement is true, I have Known Berlin many years, & believe he is as peacable and as law abiding Citizen as we have in our City, and think his Case Demands Executive Clemancy,

We the undersigned neighbours of the above petitioner H Berlin would state, that we believe his is a case that Demands the Executive Clemency, and write with him in asking your Excellency to remit Said fine, we are Satisfied that there is no more law abiding man in our city, & we believe that the account he gives of the transaction to be strictly true,

E. Webster Cox
